titlepage.titleproper: A Guide to the Papers of Hugh Scott, 1681-1987
titlepage.subtitle:
A Collection in
The Special Collections Department 10200-ab
titlepage.publisher: Special Collections Department, University of Virginia Library

defitem.label: Funding:
defitem.item: Web version of the finding aid funded in part by a grant from the National Endowment for the Humanities.

archdesc.runner: Special Collections, University of Virginia Library

did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.repository: Special Collections, University of Virginia Library
did.physdesc: There are 11,000 items (ca. 17 linear feet) in this collection.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Access to this collection is restricted to the general public until 1992. Upon removal of the access restrictions, permission for publication of material must be obtained from Scott of his designated personal representative.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p:
See the
University of Virginia Library’s use policy.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Papers of Hugh Scott, 1681-1987, Accession #10200-ab, Special Collections Dept., University of Virginia Library, Charlottesville, Va.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: This collection was given to the Library by the Honorable Hugh Scott of Falls Church, Virginia, on February 15, 1988.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Information
bioghist.p: Hugh Scott was a U.S. Senator from Pennsylvania.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: These additional papers include personal, business, financial, and political correspondence and papers; invitations; manuscripts of papers and books by Scott; oral history interviews; photographs; newspaper clippings and other printed material; bound volumes; and memorabilia, concerning Scott's political career and his private endeavors as a collector of Chinese art. There is also a bronze bust of Senator Scott sculpted by William Thompson of Athens, Georgia.

Other items include seven letters, 1860 and 1864, to Thomas R. Ware, Purser of the United States Navy and Paymaster of the Confederate States Navy, chiefly concerning the pay of men. There is also a quit- claim or release, ca. 1681-1685, signed by William Penn (1644-1718), colonizer.

arrangement.head: Organization
arrangement.p:
ORGANIZATION
I. Historical: Box 1
II. Topical: Boxes 1-17
III. Invitations: Boxes 18- 29
IV. Books by Hugh Scott: Boxes 29-36
V. Photographs: Boxes 36-40
Topical: Boxes 36-38
Hugh and Marian Scott: Boxes 38-40
VIPs: Box 40
Slides: Box 40
VI. Printed: Boxes 41-42
VII. Books: Box 42
VIII. Bound Volumes: Boxes 43-49
IX. Loose Bound Volumes (Oversize)
X. Bronze Bust of Hugh Scott
